title: Vinotherapy at Naantali Spa in Finland
text:
Vinotherapy at Naantali Spa in Finland Vinotherapy at Naantali Spa in Finland FORGET drinking the stuff, bathing in red wine is the new 'in' thing. PUBLISHED: PUBLISHED: 00:00, Fri, Jul 10, 2015 NAANTALI SPA Naantali Spa in Finland 
Well ok, it has been since the early 1990s but a recent Instagram post showing American basketball player Amar’e Stoudemire doing it has highlighted its popularity. 
Vinotherapy – it's official name I kid you not – has a number of health benefits including getting rid of cellulite and preventing wrinkles. Sold! 
So it wasn't hard to pick my treatment from nearly 100 choices during my recent visit to the Naantali Spa in Finland. 
The Galvagni Spa Wine treatment just sprung out of the menu screaming at me to indulge in it. 
Therapist Johannon began the treatment by lathering my whole body with a peel made of apricot seed powder and wine grape seed oil. Related articles Budget spa break: Soak in giant jacuzzis and indulge in... Forget drinking the stuff, bathing in red wine is the new 'in' thing 
Completely covered with the thick but amazing smelling paste, I was made to sit in a jacuzzi bath with red wine extract to allow the concoction to work its magic. 
The smell was divine and sent me straight to sleep and it was only when Johannon entered the room that I woke up. 
The treatment is completed with lashings of body cream and a glass of white wine in hand. Total bliss. 
But Naantali Spa has a lot more to offer. 
It has no less than five different pools including an outdoor pool heated to 30 degrees so you swim all year round even when there’s a blanket of snow outside. 
There’s also a gym, two Roman whirlpool baths, two Turkish and four Finnish saunas. 
Set on the edge of a seaside, the hotel makes full use of the views despite its size. 
A lot of the 251 rooms and suites have a sea view but it’s the spa residence in my opinion that has the greatest of views. 
Used for timeshare and hotel use, these are incredibly spacious with a lounge area and kitchen and come with decent size balconies. 
They are similar to modern apartments in a busy city without the hustle and bustle. 
The ample open space both inside and out provides another place to unwind and relax just metres away from the main building.. 
From a buffet to sit down fine dining and a café to lobby bar, you’ll definitely not go hungry here. 
Depending on where you choose to eat, you can find contemporary Thai, Scandinavian and continental cuisine. 
The food is simple but bold. The Le Soleil does a great grilled Salmon accompanied by potato gnocchi red curry and Asia salad. NAANTALI SPA The spa's bar 
For wine aficionados there’s a wine cellar to explore as well as embark on a course to show off your skills at future dinner parties. 
With so much to do it can prove hard to tear yourself away from the lap of luxury but it would be a shame not to see the old town with its traditional maritime charm, narrow streets, churches and museums. 
Just a short walk away, it will give you a real sense of its history, people and the history. 
A must visit is the president’s summer residence - a granite manor house on the shore of Naantalinlahti Bay surrounded by the Kultaranta Garden. 
The tradition has been ongoing since 1922 and the gardens are open to guests for free. 
Oh and how can you afford to miss Moominworld? 
The theme park - based on the Moomin books by Tove Jansson - is situated on the island of Kailo beside the old town and near Turku. 
And if you really want to take a trip down memory lane you can take advantage of Nanntali Spa’s newly launched Moomin Package which includes accommodation for a family of four in one of the Moomin Story Rooms. NAANTALI SPA Naantali Spa has a range of treatments to offer 
Just 30 minutes away, Turku is in stark contrast to Naantali. 
Once the capital of Finland, it’s now an important location for business and culture. 
Our tour guide Olga Henriksson told us that it came into existence during the end of the 13th century which makes it the oldest city in Finland. 
Sadly its ambitions were dealt a death blow in 1827 when a fire destroyed most of the city. 
Still, there is plenty to see including an impressive castle, a cathedral and museums and shops. 
And there are many restaurants to suit everyone’s budget’s but Pinella is great place to go for a bit of a splurge. 
Around 160 years old, this landmark building is situated on the River Aura in the heart of city and although contemporary in its food offerings it still gives you that lovely cosy nostalgic feeling while dining and pondering over the offerings of this part of the world. 
Nightly rates at Naantali Spa start from €69 per person on B&B basis based on 2 sharing, visit naantalispa.fi to book. Related articles
